title: 109_s352
content: The "Save Our Small and Seasonal Businesses Act of 2005" sets numerical limitations on H-2B workers. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act sets restrictions on counting aliens towards numerical limitations for nonimmigrant workers. It will be effective from October 1, 2004, to October 1, 2006, and petitions for aliens described in section 101(a)(15)(H)(ii)(b) will be accepted and processed by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act sets restrictions on counting aliens towards numerical limitations for nonimmigrant workers, effective from October 1, 2004, to October 1, 2006. Petitions for aliens described in section 101(a)(15)(H)(ii)(b) will be accepted and processed by the Secretary of Homeland Security in accordance with the Act and its amendments. SEC. 3. FRAUD PREVENTION AND DETECTION FEE. The Secretary of Homeland Security will impose a $150 fraud prevention and detection fee on employers filing petitions for nonimmigrant workers. The fee will be used for fraud prevention and detection purposes. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2005 is amended to remove references to "H1-B and L" visas in various paragraphs. Additionally, changes are made to references of section 214(c)(12) and fraud prevention activities related to petitions for nonimmigrant workers. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2005 is amended to remove references to "H1-B and L" visas in various paragraphs, including petitions for nonimmigrant status under section 214(c)(1) or (2)(A) for alien workers. Effective date for the amendments is October 1, 2005. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2005 is amended to remove references to "H1-B and L" visas in various paragraphs, including petitions for nonimmigrant status under section 214(c)(1) or (2)(A) for alien workers. Effective date for the amendments is October 1, 2005. Sanctions are imposed. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to impose penalties for failure to meet conditions or misrepresentation in petitions for nonimmigrant workers under section 101(a)(15)(H)(ii)(b). Penalties may include civil monetary fines up to $10,000 per violation and denial of future petitions filed by the employer under section 204. The Secretary of Homeland Security may delegate authority to the Secretary of Labor for penalties related to petitions for nonimmigrant workers. Penalties for willful failures to meet petition conditions involving harm to U.S. workers are the highest. 'Substantial failure' refers to willful noncompliance with petition requirements. The amendment made by subsection (a) will take effect on October 1, 2005, constituting a significant deviation from the terms and conditions of a petition. SEC. 5 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to allocate H-2B visas so that no more than 33,000 aliens enter the US under this provision in the first 6 months of a fiscal year. SEC. 6 requires the submission of information on H-2B nonimmigrants to Congress. Section 416 of the American Competitiveness and Workforce Improvement Act of 1998 is amended to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security" and requires quarterly notification to Congress on the number of aliens issued visas or nonimmigrant status. Beginning in fiscal year 2007, the Secretary of Homeland Security must annually submit information to Congress on aliens issued visas or nonimmigrant status, including their countries of origin, occupations, and compensation. In fiscal year 2007, the Secretary of Homeland Security must provide Congress with information on aliens issued visas or nonimmigrant status, including details on visa expiration, revocation, and termination, as well as the number of aliens granted nonimmigrant status in the current and previous fiscal years. If necessary, the Secretary of State will provide additional information upon request.
